Does anybody else have this? Thanks. Cheryl Dx 3/2006, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/8 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: PBI choice - baloon insert or 3D external beam ftreloar CherylRubie

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2008 07:44PM CherylRubie wrote: Hi, I am almost 2 years out, and I still have pain in my breast at times.  I had partial breast irradiation, so only 1/3 of my breast was radiated.  My rads onc said that this pain is normal when I had my check up last week.  A 1o year-old child hugged me really hard last week (large 10 year-old), and I couldn't get her to stop.  She hugged me so hard my breast hurt, and it still kind of hurts.  So I think this is normal.  My armpit doesn't hurt though, just the area of my breast that was radiated.
Posts.Title: BREAST PROBLEMS 3YRS OUT, ANYONE? NONE NONE

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 07:09PM CherylRubie wrote: You know, I tripped over my dog and fell into a stick that was poking out of a chair a few months ago (1.5 years post rads).  I hit myself EXACTLY in the incision, I couldn't believe it.  I got all yellow and black, but I didn't have any signs of lymphedema.  I asked my surgeon about it when I saw her for my check up in December, and she said it was nothing to worry about at all.  I was extreeemely painful. Cheryl
Posts.Title: BREAST PROBLEMS 3YRS OUT, ANYONE? NONE NONE

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 06:16AM CherylRubie wrote: Sue, I can't tell you what to do.  But if I had a tumor > 1cm which was Grade 3, I would do everything possible because Grade 3 is an aggressive tumor.  Also, as someone else pointed out, Triple Neg means you have fewer options.  I am surprised they suggested you for a clinical trial.  I would think a trial like that would be for <1cm and all favorable characteristics.  Again, you are you and I am me, but I would get another opinion.  Good luck and hugs! Cheryl
Posts.Title: Radiation Trial sueps LUVmy2girlZ

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 08:55PM CherylRubie wrote: Kay, I work in a hospital with patients. What I would do was to wear a dress or pants with a blazer and then have a scarf tied in front as well.  That way, I could take my bra off for most of the day while leaving the bra "dangling," and there was so much stuff there that I don't think anybody noticed.  Also, I bought a very loose bra, which I could tolerate and which gave me at least a little support.  I think I had to do this for a few weeks.  Good luck. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Partial Breast Irradiation kaydeyz kaydeyz

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 05:13PM CherylRubie wrote: Hi. Gosh, I don't remember, but I think I felt lumpy right away but that the quality of the lumps changed over time.  Are you lumpy?  I was quite sore for a while, though, and I still occasionally get shooting pains in my breast, not as bad as before.  I think that's common with all rads.  There is still kind of a "line of demarcation" between the area that was radiated and the area that was not.  The skin looks different, etc. Good luck.  Keep posting. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Partial Breast Irradiation kaydeyz kaydeyz

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2007 09:11AM CherylRubie wrote: Kay, Well, it might help you, also, we hope.  Let us know to which arm you are randomized (you might get put in the whole breast group).  Let us know how it goes.  Good luck.  I hope you have as few side effects as I did, and let us both hope that the treatment is as effective as whole breast irradiation.  Let us also remember the brave women who did lumpectomy plus radiation trials in the days when everybody was getting a mastectomy.  Thanks to them, we now know that lumpectomy + radiation = mastectomy. Best to you. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Partial Breast Irradiation kaydeyz kaydeyz

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2008 10:20PM CherylRubie wrote: Kay, About two weeks after tx ended, I had one day where I was inexplicably extremely tired all day (although I did work), then I was fine the next day.  My rads onc said that it might have been from the rads, but I don't know.  I had no problems during tx, and I was not tired at all.  I worked every day, I had rads at 8 A.M. and 5 P.M. My breast was very sore for about a month or so, I remember at work I would undo my bra which was not visible because I always wore jackets.  My breast is still very "lumpy."  I had my checkup with surgeon last week, and she says my breast is fine, but I can't really tell which lumps are normal and which are not.  Apparently, there are no problems.  My rads onc said that in her experience, people who get PBI tend to have lumpier breasts than those with WBI.  Please post how you are doing.  I'll be interested to compare experiences.  I am really glad you have this option since your tx is so far away.  Good luck! Cheryl
Posts.Title: Partial Breast Irradiation kaydeyz kaydeyz

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2007 06:03PM CherylRubie wrote: I am in that trial (see my stats below).  I had rads May '06.  I had no fatigue, my breast was sore but not as bad as many (no peeling or anything).  We just don't know about recurrences.  So far it looks good, but we are always taking a chance participating in a trial like this.  I think  that 80% of recurrences occur within the "tumor bed," and that is the rationale for PBI.  The chances of having a new tumor outside of that are are roughly equivalent to a tumor in the other breast.  That's why I decided to do it. Good luck. Cheryl
Posts.Title: Partial Breast Irradiation kaydeyz kaydeyz

Posts.Title: Accelerated Radiation Therapy - Good Idea or Bad? amyshap momof2doxies

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 10:45AM CherylRubie wrote: If your tumor is less than 1 cm and you have no positive nodes, then you are Stage I, not Stage II.  However, if you are really Grade 2, this means you have a more aggressive tumor and radiation would definitely be indicated. Another step you can take is to get the OncotypeDx test, which will tell you your risk for recurrence so you can make a better decision. Good luck Cheryl
Posts.Title: I have decided NOT to do radiation... OrliNaaman burma

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 10:47AM CherylRubie wrote: You can also consider one of the clinical trials, like accelerated partial breast irradiation.  That's what I did, and I had a total of 10 radiation treatments over the course of 5 days.  I had breast changes and pain in my breast, but no severe burns or peeling and no bad fatigue.  Mammosite is another possibility.
Posts.Title: I have decided NOT to do radiation... OrliNaaman burma

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 11:15AM CherylRubie wrote: Hi Sharon,  I see now that you are considering the partial.  You can't get a boost if you do NSABP B39.  I had read about some centers doing the prone position.  That sounds very good.  I hope you can get it.  In most parts of the country, it is very difficult to get ABPI without being in a clinical trial. You can click on my name and read all my posts about my experience with APBI with 3D external beam.  Good luck! Cheryl

Posts.Title: Worried, strange skin texture. micheled CherylRubie

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 09:05AM CherylRubie wrote: Sharon W, I had already read the research about APBI vs. WBI by the time I talked with my rads onc.  You can get this information by googling NSABP B39. That is the current Phase III trial.  There is a lot of other information available also.  There is not the same amount of research on ABPI vs. WBI-- that's the reason for the Phase III trial.  There was no mold of the breast. I haven't heard of that.  Can you tell me about it?  It's not in the B39 trial guidelines.  I did have images taken which were used by physicists to determine the radiation fields.  Regarding your last question, typically, as far as I am aware, nothing is done to protect the rest of your body.  The 3D external beam is very specific.  The areas possibly at risk are your lungs, heart, esophagus, thyroid, and probably some other areas that I don't remember.  It's not possible to avoid radiation to some of those areas, but it is much better than it was, say, in the 80s, and I don't know of any studies which suggest that ABPI is worse the WBI in that regard.  Some centers use a breathing device to lessen radiation to the lungs in ALL patients who are radiated; the one where I was treated didn't do that.  Hope this answers your questions.  Are you thinking of doing this?  You didn't say in your post. Cheryl
